entry.title: Proactive Monitoring that Integrates Retail Operations in a Data-driven World
entry.content:
Imagine a global retailer preparing for the holiday season, a time when system stability is paramount. In previous years, unexpected disruptions caused delays and customer dissatisfaction. This year, things are different. By implementing proactive monitoring powered by AI and Collective Intelligence, the retailer identified early signals of potential issues weeks before peak demand. This story exemplifies how proactive monitoring transforms support from reactive firefighting to predictive prevention.

Why Proactive Monitoring Matters

Proactive monitoring reduces escalations, improves customer confidence, and optimizes operations. Instead of waiting for incidents to occur, we anticipate them, ensuring uninterrupted business continuity. For example, during the Holiday Season Readiness Program, proactive monitoring helped SAP support teams detect anomalies in critical systems, preventing potential outages for major e-commerce customers.

How It Works

The process begins with comprehensive data collection‚Äîtelemetry from cloud systems, business process data, and historical case patterns. AI-driven algorithms then analyze these inputs to recognize patterns and correlate events. When anomalies are detected, automated workflows trigger alerts and initiate Preventive Customer Risk Mitigation actions.

Breaking Data Silos

Success depends on breaking down data silos. Only by building a Collective Intelligence framework‚Äîwhere insights from global case data, configuration logs, and usage analytics converge‚Äîcan this model be scaled across the entire customer base. As data needs to be used collaboratively, data sharing enables an environment where information is accessible in a timely manner.

Benefits

Among the benefits of proactive monitoring, they can range from faster root cause analysis to reduced mean time to resolution. The first refers to the process of identification of causes and reasons for an issue taking place, and the latter concerns the measurement of how quickly a system responds to a failure once it is recognized. Both play a part in refining the customer experience through invisible, but automated support.

With the proactive monitoring strategy anchored in AI, retailers can turn their peak shopping seasons from difficult periods into opportunities for improving customer engagement and operational resilience. A continued adoption of AI-driven capabilities is what will enable smarter planning and sustainable data-driven growth. strategic AI adoption and thoughtful implementation will drive retail excellence in an increasingly digital and data-driven world.

A special thanks to SAP experts Bharath Ramamurthy, Vice President of Strategic Initiatives, Customer Support, and Kartikaye Gomber, AI Solution Architect, for their contributions to this article.

entry.title: To the Left, To the Left: Setting Businesses Up for Irreplaceable Success
entry.content:
Consider a scenario where a critical update is scheduled for a financial services customer ahead of a major fiscal event. Traditionally, risks would surface post-deployment, leading to costly escalations. That is where a shift to the left walks into the stage: as the testing and detection steps are moved earlier into the lifecycle, an eventual delay in release is avoided, as well as the increase in costs associated with fixings issues. In other words, shifting to left is like reserving the seat in the first rows for testing!

At first glance, it may appear that risks are put in the spotlight, much like nominees at an award show. However, in reality, this approach aims at reducing them. Early recognition of potential issues enables development teams to allocate more time to data cleansing and preparation, tasks that typically consume a significant part of their efforts. This proactive approach allows for more focus on generating valuable insights rather than dealing with escalations.

What Does Shift Left Mean?

Shift Left involves moving risk detection and mitigation earlier in the lifecycle. This approach reduces downstream support costs and enhances customer satisfaction. During the Holiday Season Readiness Program, Shift Left strategies ensured that preventive controls were in place well before peak transaction periods. These strategies included:

  • Implementing Preventive Customer Risk Mitigation workflows for early alerts and automated case creation
  • Integrating with Cloud ALM for lifecycle event monitoring
  • Defining governance models for clear ownership of risk mitigation

Predictive Intelligence

Predictive intelligence uses Collective Intelligence to aggregate insights from global case data and apply AI models for event-to-issue correlation. This enables proactive actions that prevent disruptions before they impact customers.

Breaking Data Silos for Scale

Scaling this model requires dismantling data silos. By pooling insights across teams and regions, we create a unified intelligence network capable of supporting our entire customer base efficiently. With reliable data through the software deployment process, customers can make well-informed decisions at all stages of their businesses, that could lead to better budget management likewise.

Impact

This method is aligned with SAP‚Äôs vision for an effortless customer experience. It reduces escalations and downtime while improving operational efficiency. By incorporating recurrent tests at every step of the development process, the system is continuously reviewed and adjusted as needed. Just as filming involves many behind-the-scenes teams, a shift to the left ensures that the backstage engines are aware and constantly prepared for the result that customers witness.

In conclusion, the Shift Left approach changes traditional development and deployment processes by proactively addressing risks and issues earlier in the lifecycle. When customers operate their businesses smoothly and stay well-prepared, we join forces to lay the foundation for lasting success and sustained trust.

A sincere thank you to SAP experts Bharath Ramamurthy, Vice President of Strategic Initiatives, Customer Support, and Kartikaye Gomber, AI Solution Architect, for their contributions to this article

entry.title: Skills Architecture Playbook: 10 Design Decisions with Talent Intelligence Hub that Define Success !
entry.content:
The shift towards a skills-based workforce is picking up speed, and this transformation lives or dies on one thing: your skills architecture, the foundation that defines:

  • how skills are structured,
  • how they are governed,
  • how they flow through your HRtech landscape, and
  • how employees, managers, and admins actually experience them.

What‚Äôs happening -
Most organizations jump straight into ‚Äúskills projects‚Äù without stopping to define the design decisions that truly matter! I have seen SAP SuccessFactors customers engaging with different HRTech or Skills vendors separately, rather than as a coherent group. The result? Duplicate skills across systems, messy job profiles, confused employees, frustrated managers, and governance models held together with duct tape.

Think of this blog as your Skills Architecture Playbook: the 10 decisions every company must get right to build a clean, future-proof foundation with Talent Intelligence Hub. These decisions will shape everything from AI models and inference reliability to employee growth journeys and manager adoption.

If you‚Äôre implementing TIH, planning a Skills Transformation, or just trying to bring order to the skills chaos, this guide is for you.

Let‚Äôs get into the decisions that define your success.

Leading Practice Skills Architecture with Talent Intelligence Hub

Here‚Äôs a leading practice approach for designing a Skills Architecture with TIH at its core. Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners help augment and complement customers' internal data, creating a high-quality skills foundation that brings together market skills data, job and work insights, and people attributes.

Once standardized in Talent Intelligence Hub and enriched with employee and organizational master data from SuccessFactors, this unified skills intelligence can be delivered through Career and Talent Development (CTD) as the experience layer for every persona -employees, managers, HR, recruiters, and leaders.

I had shared this diagram in my session at SuccessConnect and have further explained it in my podcast. Give it a listen -  Art of the Possible - Episode 1 - Skills-based Transformation - Talent Alchemy Podcast series

This is how you bring a skills-based transformation concept to life.

1. Choose Your System of Record: Where Does Job & Skills Truth Live?

Everything starts with a single question: Where does the truth sit? 

For job architecture and skills governance, SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub should be your system of record and governance layer.

Here‚Äôs how it breaks down:

TIH + JPB = Your Master Foundation

  • Job Families
  • Job Roles
  • Job Profiles
  • Skills Library
  • Skills tagged to roles and profiles
  1. JPB holds your job architecture. 
  2. Open Skills Ecosystem partners enrich your skills library.
  3. TIH governs and standardizes everything.

Get this foundation right, and the rest of your skills strategy becomes infinitely easier.

2. Standardize Skills in the Attributes Library with AI Skills Standardization

Once you know where the truth lives, the next step is: What does that truth look like? The Attributes Library in TIH is your governance layer for all skills master data.

It helps you:

  • Maintain a clean, unified skills library.
  • Standardizes the Skills data into one common language. 
  • Manage lifecycle states (active, deprecated, standardized)
  • Standardize proficiency scales

Your Open Skills Ecosystem partner sends business- and industry-relevant skill data into TIH, where you standardize it.

This avoids:

  • Duplicate skills
  • Confusing naming conventions
  • Skill inflation
  • Random ‚ÄúHR-created‚Äù one-off skills

This is your quality control engine.

Check out my Talent Alchemy Bits and Bytes segment, where I talked about Skills Standardization. 

3. Decide How Skills Will Be Validated

If there‚Äôs one thing employees love, it‚Äôs adding skills. If there‚Äôs one thing managers love‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs being skeptical of those skills. Validation matters!

You need to decide: 

Who validates the skills?

  • Employee?
  • Manager?
  • Both?
  • Or does it depend on the skill type?

What‚Äôs the sequence?

  • Employee declares ‚Üí Manager approves
  • Manager nominates ‚Üí Employee confirms
  • System infers ‚Üí Employee validates ‚Üí Manager approves

Consistency is key.

Which system is the system of record for validation?

TIH/Growth Portfolio or your OSE partner?

Either works‚Äîjust don‚Äôt let both do it independently. That‚Äôs how data chaos is born.

4. Define Your Skills Signals Strategy

Skills come from everywhere. Projects, learning, bots, assessments‚Ä¶ even legacy tools that are somehow still alive. Your rule of survival:  SAP SuccessFactors Growth Portfolio should be the master system of record for all employee skill interactions.

That means:

  • Employees view and update skills here
  • Managers make decisions here
  • HR governs here
  • Partners feed into here

Other systems can contribute, but they can‚Äôt own the truth

5. Choose What Skills You will Infer and from Where?

Skill inferencing is magical‚Ä¶ unless it pulls the wrong signals. You need to define:

What external sources can infer skills?

  • Project systems
  • Legacy HR/LMS tools
  • External learning platforms
  • Gig/mobility platforms
  • Assessment vendors

How will you judge quality?

Set thresholds such as:

  • Evidence required
  • Confidence level
  • Relevance to job or industry
  • Duplication rules

Which SF processes continuously infer skills?

  • Learning completions
  • Internal gigs
  • Performance achievements
  • Career development activities

A thoughtful inferencing strategy prevents ‚Äúnoise skills‚Äù and keeps your profiles trustworthy.

6. Decide Where Employee Skills Data Should Flow

Once an employee‚Äôs skills are updated and validated, where does that data go?

Typical downstream consumers include:

  • Recruiting
  • Learning
  • Opportunity Marketplace
  • Workforce planning
  • Career & succession tools
  • Assessment vendors
Important: "If you have multiple skills-enabled vendors (LMS, recruiting, assessment tools), Growth Portfolio remains the master. Application partners consume standardized data; they don‚Äôt manage it. This keeps your ecosystem clean and consistent."

7. Define How the Skills Taxonomy Will Be Propagated

Your skills taxonomy flows outward from TIH into the rest of the ecosystem.

TIH is your:

  • Skills system of record
  • Job architecture governance tool
  • Standardization engine
  • Master metadata source

If you use multiple Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners:

Pick ONE to be your skills architecture provider. Why?

Because multiple skills dictionaries = chaos.
One dictionary + TIH governance = sanity.

8. Design the Employee Experience (Growth Portfolio and..)

Employees are the heart of your skills ecosystem. Decide:

How much ownership do they have?

  • Full self-declaration
  • Only inferred skills
  • Only validated skills
  • Only view or able to manage skills
  • A blended model

What should they see?

  • Validated skills
  • Inferred skills
  • Critical or core skills
  • Skill gaps

How guided should their experience be?

  • Single entry inside SuccessFactors
  • Some interactions inside partner tools
  • Or a completely unified Growth Portfolio experience

The goal?
Keep it simple, intuitive, and aligned to growth, not admin work.

9. Design the Manager Experience (Teams View and...)

Managers are where skills turn into results, development, mobility, and readiness. You need to define:

How much oversight managers have: Do they validate? Approve? Only for critical skills?

How deeply do skills feed talent decisions

Should they use skills to:

  • Recommend learning
  • Suggest gigs
  • Nominate for roles
  • Support succession plans
  • Plan team capabilities

What feedback loops they own

After:

  • Projects
  • Assignments
  • Reskilling initiatives

Manager feedback becomes key evidence for skill proficiency.

10. Design the Admin Experience (Governance, Analytics, and ...)

Admins run the heartbeat of your skills ecosystem. Define:

Who owns the skills library?

  • HR COE?
  • Talent?
  • Learning?
  • A cross-functional governance team?

How partners integrate

External vendors must feed into Growth Portfolio without duplicating or reinventing your skills.

What KPIs HR will track

Some examples:

  • % validated critical skills
  • Internal fill rate
  • Mobility rate
  • Skills coverage vs. demand
  • Time-to-proficiency
  • Learning-to-skills conversion

Conclusion: Your Skills Architecture Is Your Future

Building a skills-based organization is not about collecting skills, it‚Äôs about creating a system of truth, a system of intelligence, and most importantly, a system of experience that employees and managers trust.

  • Talent Intelligence Hub gives you the governance layer.
  • Growth Portfolio with CTD (Career & Talent Development solution) provides the experience layer.
  • Your open ecosystem partners give you the enrichment layer.

But your design decisions tie it all together.

Get these decisions right, and skills become the engine behind: talent mobility, workforce agility, learning personalization, internal career growth, and more. Get them wrong, and you‚Äôll spend months reconciling data, chasing inconsistencies, and wondering why adoption is low.

With Talent Intelligence Hub at the center and these 10 decisions guiding your journey, you can build not only an architecture, but a future-ready, human-centered skills ecosystem that actually works.

entry.title: Where Is My Stuff? ‚Äî Joule‚Äôs First Industry Release Brings AI-Driven Insight to Oil and Gas Upstream
entry.content:
The oil and gas domain has historically been one of the most stable but also conservative areas of enterprise architecture. Over multiple decades, SAP customers have evolved from custom ABAP solutions to standardized S/4HANA objects, Fiori applications, and integrated complex logistics planning and processes. While this has driven consistency and transactional efficiency, the core decision-making mechanisms in field logistics remained predominantly human-driven with, manual validation, and the experience of field and personnel.

SAP Field Logistics is a solution built on SAP S/4HANA. It is available on both S/4HANA private cloud and public cloud.  This solution enables customers leverage best in class industry practices to manage the logistics movement of their own- and third-party items between their supply and demand plants. 

We are happy to announce that in May 2025, we at SAP introduced a landmark innovation:

the very first Joule-enabled capability across all industries, delivered specifically within SAP Upstream Field Logistics.

This early release is subtle in scope but monumental in strategic significance. It marks the beginning of Field Logistics evolution from traditional business processes to a future where core FL operations become deeply AI-driven through Joule.

A Strategic First Step: Joule‚Äôs Inventory Insights for FL

The initial capability released in May focuses on a read-only non-stock inventory scenario, allowing users to retrieve consolidated product and equipment visibility through natural language and gives the latest milestone of its lifecycle to help to know where the equipment is located. Even though this first use case is intentionally controlled, it is designed as the foundation for a multi-release future where Joule will perform full field logistics (FL) transactions end-to-end.

SAP‚Äôs intention is clear:

Start small, prove value, ensure reliability, and then scale AI-driven operations across the entire upstream lifecycle.

This first release demonstrates Joule‚Äôs ability to:

  • Understand Field Logistics terminology in 50 different languages
  • Interpret users queries through Natural Language Processing and provide contextual answers instantly
  • Display list of products along with relevant information‚Äôs like plant, Purchase order, different quantities etc
  • Navigate to Manage logistics application from Joule to get a wholistic view

While simple on the surface, the underlying architecture sets the stage for powerful, future-ready logistics automation.

What This Means for Customers

 Faster, simpler access to operational intelligence

Users can ask Joule questions in natural language ‚Äî no need to navigate complex screens or interpret multiple reports.

Immediate visibility where it matters most

Inventory and material readiness have direct impact on non-productive time.

A future-proof foundation for autonomous logistics

This first release is intentionally scoped ‚Äî but designed for expansion into item receival, returns process, and more.

A clear step toward an ‚ÄúAI co-pilot‚Äù for upstream operations

Joule is not just a search tool. It is the beginning of a more intelligent, proactive, and predictive logistics environment.

Technical Highlights Behind the Scenes

While the customer experience focuses on simplicity, the technical implementation is sophisticated:

Flow Diagram

1. Semantic Understanding of FL and S/4HANA Operational Objects

Joule interprets upstream-specific structures such as:

  • Field Logistics items
  • PO, GR, Open and Return quantity
  • Latest Milestone
  • Non-stock Inventory availability data

This domain-awareness is what enables Joule to deliver precise, contextual answers.

2. Natural Language ‚Üí CDS Query Generation

Joule automatically translates plain language into data retrieval operations using:

  • CDS consumption views
  • FL OData APIs

This eliminates the need for custom queries or separate analytical tool.

Functionality:

Do follow the below link to understand about Joule and how to access the same in a Private Cloud system.

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/joule-for-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-a-comprehensive-setup-guide/ba-p/13786453

Once you login to your Fiori system as a Supply Chain Analyst persona and click on the Joule icon at the top, all the capabilities that are part of your user role will be available. Users also can click on helpful conversation starters instead of asking a question.

Certain mandatory parameters are needed to process the user utterance, for our capability the item number/ description must be provided. Additionally, optional parameters like plant could also be provided to narrow down the search results.

Joule displays a list of items that are relevant for your search along with some important fields such as PO and item, Latest Milestone.

You can click on each entry which would take you to a detail view wherein additional fields such as Order and various quantities can be viewed.

Also, there is a button at the bottom which can be used to Navigate to Manage Logistics application that filters the data already entered by the user.

 

Customer-Focused Future Roadmap

SAP has already signalled a multi-release roadmap to expand Joule‚Äôs Oil and Gas capabilities beyond visibility into actionable intelligence and automated logistics execution.

The Future Vision

This progression reflects SAP‚Äôs commitment to controlled, safe, value-driven rollout of Joule capabilities to field logistics operations.

Conclusion: A Small Release with a Massive Strategic Horizon

The May 2025 Joule capability for FL may be limited to inventory visibility, but it represents:

  • The first-ever Joule release across industries
  • The foundation of AI-enriched S/4HANA FL operations
  • The beginning of SAP‚Äôs broader AI transformation across line-of-business functions

Customers leveraging this early capability are not just gaining a new feature‚Äîthey are positioning themselves at the frontline of an industry-wide shift, where SAP systems evolve from transactional engines to intelligent co-pilots for complex field logistics operations.

entry.title: üîé Research Community Spotlight: SAP @ KD¬≤lab Karlsruhe
entry.content:
SAP and KIT Expand Research Partnership

Prof. Dr. Alexander M√§dche, head of the Human-centered Systems Lab.

SAP and the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT) are longstanding partners in academic and research endeavors. In 2019, this partnership was further institutionalized through a comprehensive framework contract for joint research initiatives, paving the way for further collaboration. 

A recent initiative exemplifies the growing partnership between SAP and one of Germany's most prestigious technical universities: the research collaboration with the Human-Centered Systems Lab (h-lab).

Led by Prof. Dr. Alexander M√§dche, the h-lab research group organized its first "Research and Innovation Symposium on Human-centered AI for Sustainable Business" in November 2025, in collaboration with Dr. Norbert Frech-Koppenhagen and Christian Boos from SAP. The event took place at Karlsruhe Decision & Design Lab (KD¬≤lab), a DFG-funded experimental lab located in the heart of Karlsruhe.

 

Business Software meets Behavioral Science

Dr. Julia Seitz registering a study participant at KD2lab (copyright: KIT/Amadeus Bramsiepe).

The KD¬≤lab at KIT is one of the world's largest computer-based behavioral science experimental laboratories. 

40 soundproof computer cubicles, climate-controlled experimental rooms, and high-resolution biosignal measurement equipment (including eye tracking, ECG, and EEG) enable researchers to capture neuro- and psychophysiological processes under controlled conditions.

Dr. Julia Seitz is Research Team Lead for two research streams at h-lab: Agentic Enterprise Systems and Biosignal-Adaptive Collaboration Systems. She combines psychological theories and behavioral economics approaches in her experimental research on human-centered information systems design.

Focusing on collaboration in teams of humans and AI agents, Dr. Seitz is particularly interested in how adaptive and agentic information systems in the workplace impact users. In her research, she combines qualitative and quantitative empirical methods with real-time processing of biosignal data to explore how agentic software design can improve outcomes and collaboration.

 

AI for Sustainability

In the collaborative project "Agentic Information Systems for Sustainability" with SAP, Dr. Seitz is working alongside Anna Sommer, SAP PhD student at KIT, to explore a crucial question: How can generative AI agents and humans work together optimally to drive sustainable business practices?

SAP PhD student Anna Sommer.Using human-centered AI design approaches and hands-on experimental research, the team is investigating the dynamic interplay between humans and generative agents, identifying which forms of interaction deliver the most impactful results.

"The project's ambition is to develop AI systems that truly complement human expertise rather than replace it: Systems that enhance rather than diminish critical thinking, enable more efficient resource management, and strengthen both ecological and social sustainability," says Anna Sommer. 

In her current study, she is investigating how the use of AI agents influences cognitive processes‚Äîparticularly critical thinking‚Äîand whether these effects differ between different AI agents. To do this, participants first complete a critical thinking test with the help of an AI agent. In a second part of the study, this test is replaced with a realistic task from the field of sustainability management requiring critical thinking. This part takes place in the KD¬≤lab and is supplemented by additional measurement methods such as eye tracking.

Ultimately, Anna Sommer's goal is to develop guidelines for AI agents that actively foster critical thinking rather than hinder it‚Äîan ability that is becoming increasingly vital for businesses striving for sustainable success.

Want to participate or know more about the partnership between SAP and KIT? Feel free to reach out to Dr. Philipp Hoffmann, Senior Data Scientist and Lead Researcher for Developer Experience at SAP, who coordinates the strategic collaboration.

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 4 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: The Factory of the Future: Production in the Age of AI, Circular Economy, and Autonomous Systems

In the debate around the supply chain of the future, one aspect is taking center stage: production as the core of modern value creation for many companies. In times of global change, digital disruption, and growing demands for sustainability, it has a key role to play.

The production of the future is networked, flexible, and data driven. Leveraging technologies such as robotics, artificial intelligence, and the Internet of Things, it is increasingly growing together with other areas of the supply chain. This development is giving rise to a digital ecosystem in which real-time data availability enables faster and more accurate decision-making across the entire supply chain.

At the same time, production is gaining strategic importance: Companies are relocating manufacturing processes closer to sales markets to reduce their dependency on global disruptions ‚Äì a trend that has been further amplified by the pandemic, energy crisis, and geopolitical tensions. In addition, there is increasing regulatory pressure and simultaneous efforts to produce more sustainably and to use resources more efficiently. All of this must be achieved while maintaining the lowest possible production costs.

In short, production is not merely one element of the supply chain, but the driving force behind its future. It determines how resilient, climate-friendly, and innovative businesses can operate tomorrow. The fourth part of the study by SAP Business Consulting and K√ºhne Logistics University on ‚ÄúSupply Chain 2035‚Äù therefore focuses on production.

The result of the study clearly highlights that the vision of a connected, AI-powered, and sustainable factory has long since arrived in the minds of many manufacturing managers ‚Äì yet its implementation is still at the beginning in many places. There is a noticeable gap in maturity between the ambitions for 2035 and today's reality. While many organizations have already formulated a clear vision for the future, operational execution often remains fragmented and experimental.

The gap in sustainability and the circular economy is particularly striking. Circular production models and closed-loop material cycles are seen as key pillars of future value creation but are currently only implemented sporadically. Product designs that facilitate recycling, reuse, and modular construction are often still in the early stages of development.

Achieving digital continuity represents another major challenge. While connected, data-driven control is considered a prerequisite for the smart factory; data landscapes are often fragmented. The lack of interoperability and inconsistent standards makes it difficult to leverage production and supply chain information end-to-end.

Similarly, the deployment of artificial intelligence falls short of expectations. Many companies are experimenting with AI-powered applications, but the leap from pilot projects to widespread deployment is still pending. In addition, data quality and availability remain critical bottlenecks. Without clean, consistent, and connected data, every digital initiative remains piecemeal. It is only on this basis that intelligent systems can be scaled, and factories can be managed holistically.

In addition, organizational structures are undergoing transformation. Many companies are moving from experimentation to scaling ‚Äì a process that requires not only new technologies, but also new skills, structures, and leadership approaches. Transforming production therefore entails not just digitalization but a fundamental shift in the interaction between people, machines, and data.

The study underscores that while the path towards the factory of the future is charted, many pillars are still under construction. Success will depend on consistently linking technological and organizational building blocks. The factory of the future will not emerge from isolated innovations, but from the integrated interplay of data, technologies, and resource-efficient processes.

Figure 1: What the Data Really Shows ‚Äì Current Studies briefly

The factory of 2035 will differ fundamentally from what we are used to today. It is no longer a production system of siloed processes, but part of an intelligent, globally connected value-creating ecosystem. Data forms its central raw material ‚Äì flowing through all systems in real time, connecting design, manufacturing, logistics, and recycling to a dynamic and adaptive cycle. The decisions are increasingly taken by artificial intelligence. It controls material flows, optimizes production plans, and detects deviations and disruptions early and preventively. Human expertise will thus shift toward strategic, creative, and monitoring tasks ‚Äì AI becomes the central instance of production.

The physical factory itself becomes autonomous and modular. Production lines adapt in real time to changing orders, materials, or energy availability. Mobile robots, self-learning systems, and digital platforms orchestrate processes largely independently.

At the same time, the paradigm shifts from linear to circular production. Closed loops are emerging; products are designed in a modular manner and optimized for reuse or remanufacturing. Digital twins and IoT data connect the physical and digital worlds. Each manufacturing step, component, and usage generates data that makes the life cycle of a product fully traceable. This digital memory not only enables precise traceability, but also predictive maintenance, accurate material returns, and the continuous improvement of future product designs.

In summary: Industrial transformation is more than technological modernization ‚Äì it is a cultural change. The factory of 2035 becomes a reality where data intelligence and circular thinking become part of the company‚Äôs DNA ‚Äì not as an isolated project, but as a foundational principle. Those who actively shape this change not only strengthen their efficiency, but also their ability to reinvent themselves in an increasingly interconnected and dynamic industry.

 

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (K√ºhne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future‚Äù.

entry.title: How far will AI go... and what will it mean for your job?
entry.content:
In April this year, I decided to voluntarily retire early from SAP after 6 years of a very interesting journey. Indeed, I've lived from the inside the infusion of powerful Artificial Intelligence capabilities in SAP Build, for application development and for process automation.

Since then, I've spent 8 months observing the IT industry evolution, particularly around AI. And now, I have very mixed feelings:

‚úîÔ∏è On one hand, I'm impressed how well SAP is positioned on the market and how SAP AI is powerful

‚ùì On the other hand, I'm more and more worried by the impact humanoid robots and AI, from SAP and all vendors, will have on so many jobs everywhere.

So I decided to share my views with you in this blog post.

SAP is amazingly well positioned with Business AI

A month ago I watched SAP TechEd Keynote and also a few sessions, and I have to say that I'm impressed. By the way, in case you missed it, watch the replay of the keynote:

I discovered AI more than 40 years ago, when I was studying to graduate in 1986 as an engineer in computing science, and 10 years ago I was working for Antidot, a french startup involved in knowledge graphs, where I wrote this white paper on Business Knowledge Graphs in 2014.

So, from my humble point of view, putting together SAP ERP + SAP Business Data Cloud + SAP Knowledge Graphs + SAP Business AI with Joule creates a winning combo. It puts SAP in a unique position , better than any competitor, to bring the best of AI to the customers.

And what has been presented and announced at SAP TechEd makes SAP even stronger:

SAP-ABAP-1 is a new model allowing to handle ABAP language: trained on more than 250 million lines of ABAP code, 30 million lines of CDS code, and extensive technical documentation, it is purpose-built to explain and generate modern ABAP code.

SAP-RPT-1 (Relational Pre-trained Transformer Model-1) is a brand new classification and regression model, allowing to better handle structured, tabular business data. It is a paradigm shift in machine learning, introducing a revolutionary approach that eliminates the security-performance trade-off entirely. SAP-RPT-1 achieves state-of-the-art performance and already outperforms regular text-based LLMs through semantic understanding of tabular relationships.

Knowledge Graph in SAP HANA Cloud is an RDF graph built from system catalog, capturing tables, columns, relationships, and annotations. It providesthe semantic layer needed for exploration, AI grounding, and graph-based reasoning. It allows agents to reason about data, to understand entities relationships, and which attributes are relevant. 

A2A and MCP protocols foster Agentic AI by allowing autonomous agents collaboration: SAP is providing out-of-the-box Joule agents and alllowing customers to create custom agents with Agent Builder in Joule Studio. Beyond that, agentic protocols such as A2A - Agent to Agent - and MCP - Model Context Protocol - with SAP Lean IX Agent Hub and Agent Mining in SAP Signavio allow to standardize, deploy and monitor AI agents collaboration.

To dig deeper on these topics, follow the links I've put in the text above, watch the replay of the SAP TechEd sessions and also refer to

  • SAP  Innovation Guide
  • SAP Guide "What is Joule?" 

What impact will AI have on human employment?

So, we all agree, SAP is doing very well with Business AI for empowering companies to do better and faster. And this is very good for SAP and its entire ecosystem.

But when it comes to employees working in these companies, things could be different. Indeed, some news popping up in mainstream media are a bit worrying. For instance, according to McKinsey & Company, AI can already do almost 60% of all the work:

Their research ‚ÄúAgents, robots, and us: Skill partnerships in the age of AI‚Äù says that the future of work will be basically shaped by partnerships among people, agents, and robots - all powered by AI. The research emphasizes that capturing AI‚Äôs massive potential economic value - about $2.9 trillion by 2023 in the US only! - depends entirely on how organizations will reorganize.

Indeed, be it for business users, for consultants, for developers, AI agents will be everywhere... and they will do a lot of tasks done by human employees today.

And we have already seen this year how big tech firms have "reorganized" to embrace AI benefits: 

  • Amazon - 30,000 layoffs
  • Accenture - 11,000 layoffs
  • Microsoft - 6,000 layoffs
  • HP - 4,000-6000 layoffs

So in total more than 50,000 jobs have been erased in a few months only. And SAP as well is shrinking its workforce: ‚ÄúIn one year, it could be one or sometimes two percent of jobs that are eliminated‚Äù said Christian Klein, and Dominik Asam  added ‚ÄúThere are certain tasks which are automated and for the same volume of output we can afford to have less people". He admits to be "brutal",  comparing this program to routines such as brushing teeth...

Meanwhile, it seems everyone is trying to reassure the public that everything will be fine‚Ä¶ perhaps to prevent tens of millions of workers from becoming upset about the prospect of losing their jobs?

Should not a part of the value created by all the AI software and humanoid robots be used to compentiate this massive loss of jobs?

Today, in many countries, health insurance, unemployment insurance, and pensions are financed by contributions paid by employers and employees on human work. If the number of employees is decreasing, shouldn't social security contributions be levied on the work performed by AI agents and humanoid robots?

Will robots embrace Karl Marx slogan? üôÉ

What do you think? How do you envision the impact AI and robots will have on your job in 3, 5 or 10 years?

Your feedback will be highly appreciated, so feel free to share your own views in the comments!

entry.title: Prompt Optimization: Unlocking Hidden Power for Enterprise AI Success
entry.content:
Gaps in Prompt Design Derail the User Experience

What happens when gaps in prompt design or user intent recognition turns everyday AI interactions into a dead‚Äëend waste of time?

Have you ever experienced this type of situation?

For example, I recently tried to claim a rebate for a kitchen appliance, but the company‚Äôs AI assistant misinterpreted my request and left me stuck with irrelevant FAQs. The issue was poor prompt design. With proper prompt optimization, the assistant could have recognized my rebate request and guided me to the correct, enabled form. A smarter workflow would have turned a dead end into a faster way to get my rebate money.

What fun!

This experience underscores a critical truth: when prompts fail to capture real‚Äëworld users‚Äô intent, the customer experience collapses.

For business and IT users working with AI, this isn‚Äôt just a consumer inconvenience, it‚Äôs a wake‚Äëup call. Prompt optimization has become a strategic discipline the bridge between user intent and AI execution. It ensures AI systems can interpret nuance, adapt to context, and deliver meaningful results.

Prompt optimization extends this discipline, helping organizations scale reliably across large language models (LLMs) and multiple AI systems so that business goals and IT execution remain aligned.

Whether in customer service troubleshooting, agentic AI-driven enterprise workflows, or customer engagement, the quality of prompts directly determines the quality of the user experience.

In this age of AI agents and assistants, refining prompts is no longer optional; it is essential for building trust, driving efficiency, enabling scalable automation, and achieving successful outcomes.

Reducing AI Project Failures - Understanding Prompt Engineering and Optimization

AI projects don‚Äôt fail because the models are weak, they fail because communication breaks down. When business intent isn‚Äôt translated into clear instructions, even the most advanced systems deliver poor results. Prompt engineering and prompt optimization have emerged as the disciplines that close this gap, turning human goals into AI assistant ready guidance.

Prompt engineering shapes the initial interaction, ensuring AI systems can interpret nuance and context. Prompt optimization builds on that foundation, refining prompts for accuracy, efficiency, and scalability across large language models (LLMs) and multiple AI systems. They enable organizations to move beyond ad hoc experimentation toward reliable, enterprise‚Äëgrade outcomes.

Together, prompt engineering and optimization form the bridge between business and IT: business teams articulate goals and context, while IT ensures technical precision and scalability. When aligned, they transform user intent into reliable AI execution.

According to a RAND report, 80% of AI project failures stem from poor human to AI communication. Misunderstandings between business and IT teams about goals, data, and capabilities are the most common cause of failure. Companies that master prompt engineering achieve significantly higher ROI compared to those relying on basic or ad hoc prompting (1).

In short: success doesn‚Äôt come from the technology alone; it comes from how we communicate with it.

Why It Matters

Prompt engineering, with prompt optimization as a key subset, is no longer a fringe skill. It is becoming a critical organizational capability embedded into everyday business functions.

According to Market Research Future (MRFR), the prompt engineering [which includes prompt optimization] market was valued at $2.195 billion in 2024 and is projected to grow to $32.78 billion by 2035, with a staggering 27.86% CAGR (2).

SAP Prompt Optimization Adoption

Prompt optimization transforms vague queries into precise instructions, guiding AI toward accurate, consistent, and actionable outputs. With AI agents and assistants like SAP‚Äôs Joule, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, and OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT, organizations recognize that prompt optimization is essential to maximize AI‚Äôs potential and align outcomes with business goals.

SAP has embedded prompt optimization into Joule, powered by the Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and Launchpad (part of the SAP Business Technology Platform) and supported by SAP‚Äôs AI Foundation, delivering enterprise‚Äëgrade accuracy and trust with Large Language Models (LLMs).

At SAP Sapphire 2025, SAP announced a proprietary Prompt Optimizer built with the company, Not Diamond. This optimizer enables enterprises to migrate and adapt prompts across multiple LLMs, supporting consistency, accelerating adoption, and improving the user experience across diverse AI systems (3).

Not Diamond envisions ‚Äúa multi‚Äëmodel AI future, with thousands of foundation models, millions of fine‚Äëtuned variants, and billions of custom inference engines running on top of them.‚Äù Their infrastructure routes, governs, and scales prompts across these systems, ensuring flexibility and trust.

This partnership confirms prompt optimization as an important, core enterprise requirement, bridging business strategy with technology capabilities for responsible AI.

From Hard‚ÄëCoded Prompts to Agentic AI Orchestration

Currently, there is a larger shift from static prompt engineering toward dynamic, context‚Äëaware orchestration. Agentic AI is evolving as the inevitable evolution.

In this rebate example handling with prompt optimization means hard‚Äëcoding keywords such as ‚Äúrebate‚Äù and product numbers and writing scripts to manually enable the routing to the appropriate form. It requires constant upkeep.

In the future, agentic AI changes the flow entirely. Instead of static prompts, the agent recognizes, in the rebate example, the intent dynamically, queries the product database directly, and routes requests to backend systems without manual intervention.

Responses adapt in real time, errors trigger self-correction cycles, and product updates sync automatically with the catalog.

This rebate scenario shows the shift from today‚Äôs manual prompt engineering to tomorrow‚Äôs agentic orchestration moving from scripted rules to adaptive intelligence.

Best of Prompt Optimization Capabilities

Prompt optimization is the discipline that converts AI potential into measurable business outcomes, delivering benefits such as:

  1. Clarifies Intent ‚Äì Ensures AI understands user goals, reducing miscommunication and aligning outputs with business needs.
  2. Customer Engagement & Personalization ‚Äì Crafts prompts that drive tailored chatbot interactions, outreach, and recommendations, fostering loyalty and satisfaction.
  3. Structures Outputs ‚Äì Guides AI to deliver usable formats (tables, lists, reports, narratives) for clarity and consistency.
  4. Improves Efficiency & Operational Automation ‚Äì Minimizes unnecessary token usage, accelerates turnaround, and empowers agentic AI to automate repetitive workflows such as reporting, summarization, and FAQ handling.
  5. Adds Domain Context ‚Äì Embeds industry‚Äëspecific language, governance and compliance rules, approved product names, synonyms, and brand tone for relevance.
  6. Supports Scalability Across Teams ‚Äì Builds reusable prompt libraries and frameworks that allow consistent enterprise‚Äëwide adoption without reinventing workflows.
  7. Content Quality & Consistency ‚Äì Ensures outputs are brand‚Äëaligned, accurate, and emotionally resonant across all channels.
  8. Optimizes Across Models ‚Äì With tools like Not Diamond‚Äôs Prompt Optimizer, prompts can be migrated and adapted across Copilot, Gemini, ChatGPT, Joule, and other LLMs.
  9. Enhanced Accuracy & Decision‚ÄëMaking ‚Äì Produces precise, consistent outputs and extracts actionable intelligence quickly to support better business decisions.

By uniting these capabilities, prompt optimization becomes the foundation for trustworthy, scalable, and business‚Äëaligned AI success.

Short on Time? Who Manages Prompt Engineering

The shift from prompt engineering to agentic AI isn‚Äôt just the domain of IT or developers. It is opening up a wave of business‚Äëfriendly, low‚Äëcode/no‚Äëcode opportunities.

Consultants, contractors, and employees can create value by helping organizations design, deploy, and optimize AI workflows without deep computer science level programming.

Examples include:

  • Prompt Engineer (Business‚Äëoriented) ‚Äì Designs and optimizes prompts for customer service, marketing, and enterprise workflows.
  • Agentic AI Workflow Designer ‚Äì Uses low‚Äëcode tools to connect AI agents with backend systems, automating rebate claims, reporting, and customer engagement without heavy coding.
  • AI Solutions Consultant ‚Äì Advises companies on integrating agentic AI into existing processes, bridging IT and business teams.
  • No‚ÄëCode AI Developer ‚Äì Builds AI‚Äëpowered applications using drag‚Äëand‚Äëdrop platforms and reusable prompt libraries.
  • AI Product Owner / Business Analyst ‚Äì Guides adoption by mapping workflows, defining requirements, and ensuring AI agents align with business goals.
  • AI Governance & Compliance Specialist ‚Äì Establishes rules for prompt libraries, agentic workflows, and data handling.

In fast‚Äëpaced, short‚Äëhanded work environments, these specialists provide focus and discipline, coach key stakeholders with standard operating procedures (SOPs), monitor performance, and refine prompts as business needs evolve ensuring AI systems remain accurate, consistent, and trusted across the enterprise.

Final Thoughts

Prompt optimization and its refinement through prompt optimization evolving into agentic AI is no longer a niche skill or technical curiosity; it has become a core business capability that drives efficiency, compliance, and innovation.

Organizations that embrace it gain a competitive edge, while those that neglect it risk wasted investments and inconsistent results.

By embedding prompt optimization as a business standard, integrated into workflows through enterprise‚Äëwide libraries, governance, and automated refinement, companies can optimize AI strategies to keep pace with evolving models, regulations, and customer expectations.

The future of enterprise AI will not be defined by those who merely explore prompts and agentic AI, but by those who master prompt optimization and agentic AI, transforming raw model potential into trusted, scalable business value.

And as a result, users who want to get their rebates processed can save time by getting answers versus gaps and dead ends.

entry.title: Engineering AI Transparency: Ideation and validation (Part 1)
entry.content:
Introduction 

Aviation safety became non-negotiable because stakeholders agreed on a clear definition: keeping humans alive and systems operational. For AI, the definition is less obvious and varies by use case. We define AI safety as systems operating within intended boundaries without causing harm: technical, ethical, or societal, as beautifully explained by Bettina Laugwitz in her introductory blogpost of this series (Keep the blue side up: Building trust in AI throug... - SAP Community). This means being lawful, ethical, and robust, echoing the principles outlined in global AI governance frameworks such as ISO/IEC 42001 and related regulations such as the EU AI Act. ISO/IEC 42001:2023 - AI management systems, EU Artificial Intelligence Act | Up-to-date developments and analyses of the EU AI Act, Standards, frameworks, and legislation for artificial intelligence (AI) transparency | AI and Ethics 

A ‚Äúsafe‚Äù AI system should: 

  • Comply with laws and standards (LawfulAI)  
  • Respect human rights and agency (EthicalAI)  
  • Perform reliably under expected and edge conditions (RobustAI)  

These pillars form the foundation for engineering transparency in AI systems. Drawing lessons from aviation‚Äôs hard-earned safety culture, this first part of a two-part blogpost around engineering practices around AI transparency (which is part of a bigger series of Responsible AI blogposts around AI transparency), explores how aviation engineering principles and planning can help inform AI transparency related practices within the AI innovation lifecycle (see also the respective checklists in the SAP AI Ethics Handbook). This first part focuses on the early stages of ideation and validation which can help bring transparency to the center of all our AI innovation planning. The second part focuses on the next stages, including: Realization, Productization, and Operations. (Part 2)

For ‚ÄúTransparency & Explainability‚Äù in AI systems to progress beyond aspirational slogans; they must be engineered into the product, the pipeline, and day-to-day operations, with clear roles for every stakeholder. Overview of transparency and inspectability mechanisms to achieve accountability of artificial intelligence systems | Data & Policy | Cambridge Core, Evaluating Transparency in the Development of Artificial Intelligence Systems: A Systematic Literature Review. Let's look at how.

AI's Captain and the crew: Stakeholder Requirement Mapping 

In aviation, roles are clearly defined: pilots, air traffic controllers, maintenance crew, and cabin staff, each have specific responsibilities and access to information. Pilots see cockpit instruments not the engineering schematics; maintenance teams get technical manuals, not passenger safety cards. This layered approach ensures clarity without unnecessary information overload. Similarly, transparency must be tailored to the different roles. Engineers need deep technical details while end users need simple actionable explanations of the system they are interacting with. 

What does it include: A persona mapping exercise should be conducted in the early ideation stage for the AI feature to identify stakeholders including engineers, product owners, compliance teams, end users, etc. and their transparency needs should be detailed out. Role-based access to information should follow the least privilege principle. Further to this mapping exercise, there should be a clear assignment of accountabilities related to transparency checkpoints(decided on a case to case basis). Questions like: who approves product updates, who updates the documentation, who monitors compliance, etc. Should be answered by the use case team and related mapping should be embedded into the design documents and backlog items early in the lifecycle. 

In practice: An established approach to identify user roles, users‚Äô objectives, and their (information) needs is conducting early-stage design workshops (e. g. following the SAP AppHaus‚Äô Business AI Explore or Design workshop methodology).  

Navigating tough terrains: Classifying use cases 

For planning appropriate contingency measures, scenarios within aviation sector are classified into different categories, based on weather conditions, passenger load, aircraft readiness, etc. Similarly, it is important to classify AI use cases into different categories early on to decide the extent of transparency measures to be implemented within the use case to mitigate the associated risks appropriately. 

What does it include: This would include classification based on low, medium, high impact (on individuals for e.g.), critically of the sector in which the use case is operationalized (HR, Finance being on the higher criticality side), automation levels (fully automated decision-making being highly critical), tool access (especially for agent use cases, in order to avoid cascading harms), regulatory exposure (For e.g. healthcare being highly regulated), etc. Considering this classification, for appropriate transparency: 

  • Human oversight mechanisms should be appropriately adjusted.  
  • Retention period for the audit logs should be proportional to the impact. 
  • High impact use cases should have rollback mechanisms and hence related documentation. 
  • Impact should be linked to internal responsible AI policies around transparency. 

In practice: At SAP, every AI use case goes through the AI Ethics Review process that categorizes them into different categories according to the respective ethical impact. A detailed blogpost around the AI ethics governance process at SAP will be published soon as part of this blogpost series around AI transparency. For now, to learn more about how the process works, please refer to the SAP AI Ethics Handbook (chapter ‚ÄúPrinciples into action‚Äù) in which categorization criteria and governance setup are described in more details (or watch the ‚ÄúGoverning AI Ethics at SAP‚Äù lesson of the SAP Learning Journey ‚ÄúPutting AI Ethics into Practice at SAP‚Äù).  

AI's Pre‚Äëflight checklists: Transparency & explainability prerequisites 

Airplanes are never shipped without a complete ticked off checklist. Similarly, AI features should never be shipped without passing a Transparency & explainability checklist. This list should also be passed down the chain to relevant stakeholders who can then use this at different checkpoints and keep an eye out for deviations and document these parameters. This not only includes architectural transparency, but also other components of overall engineering side of AI development related quality checks focusing on transparency and explainability which should be provided to relevant stakeholders within the enterprise and to the system admins at the customer/user side. 

What does it include: A pre-flight checklist for AI transparency should mandate architectural transparency by documenting system purpose, data sources, model type, and limitations; confirm explainability readiness wherever AI influences outcomes; and verify compliance hooks aligned with regulatory anchors like the EU AI Act. This checklist must integrate into the development workflow by linking items to backlog tools and making transparency a release gate item. No feature ships without proof of appropriate transparency and explainability. It should also be distributed across stakeholders including architects, QA, product owners, and system admins, with checkpoints for deviations during lifecycle changes (something on the lines of SAP Design System Guidelines). Alongside this, evidence packs should be stored in a central repository linked to project management tools for auditability. Finally, for high-risk AI systems, add enhanced monitoring and troubleshooting documentation for deployment and operations to ensure resilience and compliance. 

In practice: Transparency and explainability requirements are very different for different application contexts, situations and user personas (as explained in this blogpost: Trustworthy AI: How to make artificial intelligenc... - SAP Community). The SAP Fiori Design Guidelines for explainable AI take this variety of expectations into account by differentiating between L1/L2/L3 explanations: Level 1: Minimum explanation level for quick overview; Level 2: Condensed view of the relevant properties, amounts and contextual information; Level 3: Extended report specifically for advanced users covering details around the AI performance, further context and conditions for monitoring AI operations). Applied to an SAP use case, the need for end-user transparency is very obvious when it comes to HR related contexts, e. g. candidate analysis in recruiting. In the Learning Journey lesson ‚ÄúEnsuring Explainability in HR AI Systems‚Äù, our experts share how the team addressed the requirements during implementation.   

Closing 

Transparency isn‚Äôt a checklist you tick once, it‚Äôs a culture that starts at ideation and validation and continues through every stage of the AI lifecycle. By embedding stakeholder mapping, risk classification, and compliance gates early, we create a foundation where trust is engineered, not promised. These steps ensure that transparency is not an afterthought but a design principle that shapes every decision.  

In the next blog post, we‚Äôll move beyond planning and delve deeper into practice, exploring how transparency can be operationalized during realization, productization, and operations stages, with concrete engineering patterns(Part 2). Together, these two parts outline key engineering practices for integrating transparency into AI systems aligned with the principles of lawfulness, ethics, and robustness. 

 

Let's keep sharing how AI transparency helps keep_the_blue_side_up

 

Stay tuned for the next part of this blogpost with further deep dive into the engineering practices around AI transparency!!

entry.title: The Hidden Behavior of LLMs - Prompt Caching and Determinism
entry.content:
The Hidden Behavior of LLMs - The LLM Prompt Caching and Determinism
Are LLMs Really Stateless?

A Developer‚Äôs Deep Dive Into the Hidden Behavior of LLMs (with code-gen as the use case)

In this article, I explore three questions that emerged during my testing: why LLMs appear stateful, why prompt updates improve accuracy, and why outputs vary even with temperature set to zero.

Introduction: The "Wait, What?" Moment

I recently started building a code generation tool using Large Language Models (LLMs) via API calls. Like many of you, I learned the golden rule of LLM development early on: LLMs are stateless. They don‚Äôt "remember" past requests; every API call is a fresh start.

But as I tested my tool, I noticed something that confused me.

  1. Whenever I made changes in my prompt instructions: The output was perfect!
  2. When I changed nothing and sent the exact same request: The output still changed!

I expected that if the inputs were identical (and the model is stateless), the result should be consistent. This inconsistency led me down a rabbit hole of research where I landed on a feature that completely changed how I optimize my workflows: Prompt Caching.

If you are building AI Agents or Code Gen tools on SAP BTP (using SAP Generative AI Hub) or directly via provider APIs, this is a mechanism you need to understand‚Äînot just for speed, but to clear up the "caching" misconception.

The Myth Buster: "Prompt Cache" NE "Response Cache"

Here is the inference I made during my research, which might clear up your confusion too:

The Reality: Prompt Caching does not cache the answer. It caches the question.

When we hear "Cache" in software development (like SAP ABAP or SAP HANA), we think of storing the result to serve it instantly next time. Prompt Caching is different. It caches the pre-computation of your input context (the Key-Value states of the attention mechanism). It essentially "pre-loads" the model's brain with your long documents, codebases, or instructions.

However, the generation of the response is still calculated fresh, token by token. This brings us to the second major realization‚Äîwhy your output changes even when the prompt doesn't.

The "Temperature=0" Trap: Why It‚Äôs Still Not Deterministic

You might think, "If the prompt is cached and I set Temperature to 0, shouldn't the output be identical every time?"

The short answer: No.

The technical answer: Modern LLMs are only "mostly" deterministic, even at Temperature=0.

While setting the temperature to 0 forces greedy decoding (always picking the highest-probability next token), real-world infrastructure introduces subtle variations:

  1. Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) Architecture: Models like GPT-4 are believed to use a "Sparse MoE" design. Different "expert" subnetworks handle different parts of your input. Parallel routing and slight gating differences can introduce non-determinism in the path your data takes.
  2. GPU "Fuzziness": Modern GPUs perform massive parallel operations. Because floating-point arithmetic is non-associative, the order of operations can shift slightly based on thread scheduling. A microscopic rounding error can flip a token choice when two words have nearly identical probabilities.
  3. System Variance: Your request might hit a different backend instance or hardware generation (indicated by the system_fingerprint in OpenAI responses).

The Takeaway: Even with a cached prompt and zero temperature, expect minor "drift" in your outputs. The prompt cache speeds up the input processing, but the output generation remains subject to the complex physics of AI hardware.

How It Works: Implicit vs. Explicit

Different vendors handle this differently. If you are using models via SAP Generative AI Hub, it's crucial to know how the underlying models behave.

Implicit Caching (The "It Just Works" Approach)

Vendors: OpenAI (GPT-4.1), Google (Gemini)

  • Mechanism: You don't need to change your code. If the API detects that the first 1,024+ tokens of your prompt match a previous request sent recently, it automatically uses the cached processing.
  • Pros: Zero developer effort.
  • Cons: Less control over what stays in the cache.

Explicit Caching (The "Precision" Approach)

Vendor: Anthropic (Claude 3.5 and > Sonnet/Haiku)

  • Mechanism: You must explicitly tell the API where to stop caching. You insert a cache_control parameter at a specific "checkpoint" in your message history.
  • Pros: You guarantee that your heavy context (like a full ABAP codebase or API specification) is cached.
  • Cons: Requires a small code change.

A Common Practice for Agentic AI & Code Gen

In my code generation use case, I send the entire project context (libraries, style guides, and current code) with every request. Without caching, this is slow and expensive.

The Strategy:

Organize your prompt so the static content is at the top.

  1. System Prompt (Static: "You are an ABAP Expert...")
  2. Context/Documentation (Static: "Here is the SAP Cloud SDK documentation...") -> [CACHE CHECKPOINT]
  3. User Query (Dynamic: "Write a method to fetch Business Partners.")

By placing the checkpoint after the documentation, the model "reads" the docs once. For every subsequent user query, it skips the heavy lifting and jumps straight to generating code.

Verifying the Speed Up: Analyze Your Logs

How do you know it's working? You won't see "same output," but you will see "faster time-to-first-token."

Look at the usage metadata in your API response.

  • OpenAI: Look for cached_tokens in the usage object.
  • Anthropic: Look for cache_read_input_tokens.
  • Google Gemini: Look for cachedContentTokenCount.

Example Analysis:

  • Request 1 (Cold): Input Tokens: 10,000 | Processing Time: 4.5s
  • Request 2 (Warm): Input Tokens: 10,000 (9,900 Cached!) | Processing Time: 0.8s

Why could this be a game-changer?

  • Latency: The model doesn't have to "read" your 5,000-line code file every time. It "remembers" the reading process.
  • Cost: You pay significantly less (often ~90% less) for the cached tokens.

If you see the processing time drop drastically while the output remains high-quality (and slightly varied), you have successfully implemented Prompt Caching.

My Personal Inference: The "Bad Roll" & The Butterfly Effect

During my testing, I encountered a frustrating scenario that I believe many developers will face.

  • The Scenario: I used OpenAI for code generation. When the prompt was cached (no changes), the code quality was consistently "not perfect"‚Äîit had minor bugs or incomplete logic.
  • The Fix: When I added just one single word to the prompt, the code generation suddenly became perfect.
  • The Contrast: Switching to Anthropic (without caching) gave me complete code every time.

Why did adding one word fix the OpenAI output? This is what I call the "Deterministic Trap." When you use a cached prompt with a low temperature (which we usually do for code), the model is mathematically locked into a specific "reasoning path." If the model generates a suboptimal solution (a "bad roll") on the first try, the cached state ensures it starts from the exact same mathematical position next time. It essentially "remembers" the path to the bad answer.

By adding a single word, I forced a "Cache Miss" (or at least a perturbation in the attention mechanism). This acted like the "Butterfly Effect"‚Äîit shifted the token probabilities just enough to force the model to calculate a fresh path, allowing it to escape the "bad roll" and find the correct solution.

The Lesson: Prompt Caching is powerful for speed, but if you notice your model is "stuck" giving you the same bad code repeatedly, don't just retry. Change the prompt. Even a single extra adjective can shake the model out of a local minimum and produce the perfect result.

Conclusion

LLMs are stateless, but Prompt Caching gives them a "short-term memory" for processing inputs. While it won't force your outputs to be bit-for-bit identical (due to MoE and GPU nuances), it will make your applications significantly faster and cheaper to run.

Next Step: Check your current API logs. If you are sending long contexts (>1024 tokens) repeatedly, you might already be benefiting from implicit caching, or you may need to add cache_control headers for Anthropic models to unlock these savings.

References & Further Reading

  • Anthropic Prompt Caching: (https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/prompt-caching)
  • OpenAI Prompt Caching: (https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/prompt-caching)
  • Google Gemini Context Caching: (https://ai.google.dev/gemini-api/docs/caching)
  • SAP Generative AI Hub: (https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-ai-core/generative-ai-hub)
